text: Glad to be part of this exciting group

Rough notes for the Identity Kickoff meeting are at <https://docs.google.com/document/d/1fLqOQcOxpbNQfjgHioV02lbR53XFzKwqUrv-4goN_sA/edit?usp=sharing> — feel free to clean up your comments and statements, and I will share later to broader community.
The ID 2020 Summit on digital identity at the United Nations in NYC, May 20th: <http://id2020summit.org>
The ID 2020 Design Workshop following the workshop <http://www.WebOfTrust.info>, also in NYC on May 21st and 22nd.

text: Cambridge Blockchain has some specific "identity only" use cases that might be relevant to add to the use case GitHub pages (such as validating KYC-supporting information for high net worth clients of a bank).  In addition, I see that there are some references to identity and privacy in the use case templates.  We'd be happy to participate in some type of "cross-cutting" evaluation of identity and privacy across all use cases when Patrick Holmes' team gets to that point.
A good addition to use cases might be whether they need to run a basic OFAC AML screen: <http://apps.finra.org/rulesregulation/ofac/1/Default.aspx>
I am waiting on the closure of the Architecture WG Doodle poll before posting ours. If you are part of architecture WG, please answer that poll <http://doodle.com/poll/reqqt7iqanqeceui> soon!

Is there a sample for using Transaction Certificate on chaincode?
<@U11TAFPUP>: i think the support is still emerging, but you can get a taste here: <https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/pull/1212>

attachments.title: Example of a chaincode using role-based access control (RBAC) by adecaro · Pull Request #1212 · hyperledger/fabric · GitHub
attachments.text: The PR contains a chaincode showing how to implement role-based access control using TCerts. This addresses Issue #1207. Signed-off-by: Angelo De Caro <mailto:adc@zurich.ibm.com|adc@zurich.ibm.com>
attachments.fallback: GitHub: Example of a chaincode using role-based access control (RBAC) by adecaro · Pull Request #1212 · hyperledger/fabric

text: <@U11TAFPUP> - you can start with the example <@U0KPFAZNF> mentions and they'll be some updates coming soon as well as documentation on how this all works and the relevant APIs provided by the fabric.  This will also become more clear when the Client SDK is completed as you'll actually have more control of TCerts so you can get a better idea how things works

but the basic idea is that the fabric provides a set of APIs in the chaincode shim which allows you to interrogate TCerts for various attributes which you can then use within your chaincode to provide access control, assign owners to assets, etc
<@U0UFDAS91>: Hi Chris, if there is call-in information for the meeting tomorrow, would you mind posting a link to that here?  Thanks.

file.name: Notes_from_afternoon_Security_overview
file.title: Notes from afternoon Security overview
file.preview:
First, I want to apologise for a misunderstanding. When I said I was taking "some" notes, I didn't mean that I would take a full set of notes that would reflect the whole session, and I didn't. Nonetheless, here is a best-effort summary based on notes I did take that I wanted to capture.

Given that they are incomplete and probably inaccurate, perhaps we could discuss in Slack and if it makes sense I can transfer a summary to the wiki.

text: <@U11C7DZU5>: I appreciate the clarifications! Much we still need to learn and share.
<@U0UFDAS91>: I’ll be attending ID2020. Looking forward to seeing you there.

<@U0UFDAS91>: yes indeed.  <@U16Q0J0E6> I failed to draw your attention to this post: <https://hyperledgerproject.slack.com/archives/identity/p1462503188000094>, where I hopefully didn't mischaracterize you too badly.  It would be good to get your reaction to it.  I'm particularly interested to know where I can see the most up-to-date descriptions of the overview you gave at the F2F (assuming I am correct that the protocol-spec document isn't it).  Thanks.  It was great meeting you and learning from you!

text:
Hi, 
Are there any existing bibliography or usecases around identity management that i can refer to.
I run a chaincode with security setup.
I invoked the chaincode. it was okay.
But if I queried the chaincode,
"Error when querying chaincode: Error:Failed to launch chaincode spec(Failed to init chaincode(handler not found for chaincode ABC)"

Regarding the list of use cases Jeremy posted at  <https://github.com/hyperledger/hyperledger/wiki/Identity-WG---Use-Cases-Inventory>, it seems to me that some good next steps would be: 1) add some more detail to each of these use cases, particularly with regard to what requirements each use case places on identity 2) arrive at a consolidated and somewhat prioritized list of requirements for identity from #1.   Thoughts?  Or maybe the requirements are clear to others from these use cases?

text: Sorry for the very late notice, but I just returned from travel and we are not prepared to present "updated slides on the identity architecture used in Fabric" on Wednesday at 9am PT (noon ET). Per the note from May 5th, we thought the "The next meeting will be Thursday May 19, 11am ET (8am PT)." Please advise regarding a date on which we should present (and incorporate answers to questions from <@U11C7DZU5> and interested others).

Thanks for the response <@U16Q0J0E6>.  I look forward to consuming what you produce when you are able to produce it.  I do hope to call will be recorded, but anyway I think having up-to-date written materials that are hopefully accessible to mortals such as myself is a more important end goal.  As mentioned, I'm happy to provide feedback from the perspective of said mortal.  Thanks.

text: <@U17GHSSFR|singhvi> pinned a message to this channel.
Hi <@U0UFDAS91> , is there a link to follow through the ID 2020 summit

Hello guys, I have a question regarding fabric Membership Service. 

In the glossary, it says that this is a node which purpose is to provide different types of certificates for different entities. But it says it's owned by "third party service provider"... Is this necessarily so?

Can't my network has its own Membership Service node? Are there fabric modules or endpoints that help with such functionalities? Or would I have to implement the certificate issuing myself? (in case I don't want to rely on third party authorities)

<@U1ENXTQRL>: I think (though I’m not positive as I didn’t write the glossary) that they may have been implying that the Membership Services component is not currently decentralized. My understanding is that there is work underway to decentralize the functionality.
Oh, it's much clearer now. Thank you <@U0TFEHX8E>.
In any case, I'm guessing I can configure a node (or various nodes) such that the network itself acts as the CA, RA, and even TLS-CA (maybe even all of those in a single node)?

<@U1ENXTQRL>:  not quite sure what you mean here, but if you are implying that the peer nodes themselves can provide this functionality then the answer is no.  You'll still need to run the membersvcs executable.  You are correct in that you can run one single instance of memberscvs in order to handle the ACA,ECA,TCA and TLS functions

<@U0PB67X4K>:  Yes, that's what I meant. If there could be a special node _within_ the network that served as a "Certificate Authority", without having to trust in a third party. As far as I'm understanding, the answer to that is yes, right?
<@U1ENXTQRL>:   yeah - you can run your own "Certificate Authority" node which only your network interacts with with no reliance on a 3rd party to run it for you

text: To do that, I had to create a fork of the repo, upload the doc to the  fork, and then create a pull request to merge it into the master branch. The continuous integration build failed because there is nothing to build in this repo (just 3 documentation files). Ry kindly override the build failure at my direct request to accept the fork back into master. (There is no code because it is in the other repos.)

The recording of last week's presentation in the Identity WG call on IBM Fabric Membership Services Architecture is at <https://meetings.webex.com/collabs/url/i-271A2F8IRqjuDCoiWed_-ISAS5bOQTOm-1Vi5O_GS00000>

Hi <@U0UFDAS91>, thanks for everything! Please let me know if I can assist in any way.

*Hyperledger Identity WG Biweekly Meeting*

The Hyperledger Identity WG has a regular meetings biweekly (every other week — 13 Jul, 27 Jul, 10 Aug, 24 Aug) alternating with Architecture WG, at 12pm EDT (9am PDT) using WebEx.

*Next Meeting*

Our next meeting will be 13 July, at 12pm EDT (9am PDT). The topic of this meeting is a followup with David Kravitz to the presentation two weeks ago on the IBM’s Membership Services architecture as used by Hyperledger Fabric.

The recording of the last Identity WG meeting on IBM’s Membership Services architecture as used by Hyperledger Fabric is available at: <https://meetings.webex.com/collabs/url/i-271A2F8IRqjuDCoiWed_-ISAS5bOQTOm-1Vi5O_GS00000>

The slides for this last meeting are at: <https://www.dropbox.com/s/d4geya90fbv3kw2/Hyperledger%20Membership%20Services%20Presentation%20June%2029%202016.pdf?dl=0>

*Meeting Details*

You can join the WebEx at <https://meetings.webex.com/collabs/meetings/join?uuid=M13E85PQ13KWSMVJJLZ1FZ3XNX-9VIB>

Or you can join by phone:

<tel:+1-408-525-6800|+1-408-525-6800> Call-in toll number (US/Canada)
<tel:+1-866-432-9903|+1-866-432-9903> Call-in toll-free number (US/Canada)
Access code: 190 609 401
Google Docs Shared Notes for meetings are at: <https://docs.google.com/document/d/1nVkjhSlghjc4KFWEYDU2B0ztWCFh1CK8a7VmqwFsnKY/edit?usp=sharing>

*More Info*

Contact: Christopher Allen, Blockstream <mailto:ChristopherA@Blockstream.com|ChristopherA@Blockstream.com>

text: Hi all, I just joined as I wanted to discuss a proposal I made to Christopher Allen last week who kindly suggested to post it here. You can read the proposal below so any feedback and thoughts would be more than welcome.

Pluggable Membership Service Member Connector proposal

1. Motivation

During development of recent blockchain implementation, we ran into a problem where we had user information, including login, stored outside of the hyperledger.

Importing users through yaml or gRPC is not optimal as it can eventually duplicate the enterprise user directory. On top of that, systems usually keep creating new users even after the initial import. This means that not only we need to initially import the users, but also sync the external user directory with hyperledger whenever external system creates a new user.

This process leaves user creation in blockchain, which is a very important authentication factor, very error prone. This will usually happen for enterprise customers having large number of users.

2. The possible solution 

We could let membership service optionally externalize users. This could work by implementing a pluggable Member Connector interface.

Membership service could be configured through a property to use a implementation of the Member connector interface.

Once configured, this implementation of the interface would be getting user information from external user directory and returning required information to the Membership service, just as it happens for users added through either member yaml files or gRPC interface.

As a part of this story, we could provide sample implementations of the Member connector interface implementations for the most common types of external user directories (LDAP, SQL DB, etc...).

The sample could be shipped as part of hyperledger and would serve two purposes. First would be that customers do not to do any coding to connect to most common user directories. And the second would be to provide guidelines in case they would need to implement Member connector for some less common type of user directories they are using. This is to ensure the Member connector can link to anything, if required.

I see one problem over here : The Enterprise LDAP will need to provide you something like LDAP filter to get info out from LDAP that can be consumed by Membership services , whereas in asserted Identity model Enterprise application will provide all the information without providing directory details.
Publishing LDAP filter has potential of exposing their directory structure.

Ksarin,  It's good ideal and use your ideal.  This how I see it,   we should split  the  membersrvc.yaml   one of them contains Enrollusers information (ECA/ACA)     the interface you suggested will connect to that member yaml.

A reminder that our next Hyperledger Identity WG meeting will be tomorrow, Wednesday Oct 5th, at 12pm EDT /  9am PDT.

The topic of this meeting is the Hyperledger Sawtooth Endpoint Registry, which will be hosted by Mic Bowman of Intel <mic.bowman@intel.com> (I will be out-of-country).
